Description: Thebes, the Colossi of the Memnon; with figures and camels beneath the two monumental sculptures. 1866 Watercolour and bodycolour; framed
Curator's comments: This watercolour drawing is one of three works by Henry Stanier in the British Museum’s collection, all depicting Egyptian views (for further information, see the curatorial comment on his view of Karnak, 1994,U.10; the other view is of Cairo 1994,U.8). The present drawing depicts the Colossi of Memnon at the ancient site of Thebes in the modern day city of Luxor. The two statues represent Pharaoh Amenhotop III (14th century BC) and originally served to guard the entrance of an extensive temple complex now lost. Another work depicting 'The Colossi of Memno, South of the Valley of the Kings at Sunset: The Pyramids from across the Nile in Moonlight' was included at a sale at Sotheby’s on April 19, 1978. Register states: "In Original frame".
Associated places: Topographic representation of: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt)
Acquisition notes: This item has an uncertain or incomplete provenance for the years 1933-45. The British Museum welcomes information and assistance in the investigation and clarification of the provenance of all works during that era. Not known how acquired. Found in frame-store in December 1994.
